top sleeve circumference e - yoke depth at front xs 32 3 12 18 10 15 11 5 7 5 1040 1200 s 34 3 12 19 11 15 12 8 1160 1300 sm 36 5 3 12 19 11 16 12 5 8 25 1220 1400 m 38 3 12 20 11 16 13 8 5 1300 1500 ml 40 4 13 20 12 17 14 25 9 1440 1640 l 42 4 13 21 13 18 15 9 25 1580 1800 xl 46 4 13 21 13 18 5 16 9 5 1720 1980 xxl 50 4 13 21 14 19 17 5 10 1940 2200 3xl 55 5 5 14 21 14 20 19 10 5 2180 2520 4xl 60 5 5 14 21 14 20 20 11 2280 2660 5xl 65 5 14 21 14 20 21 11 5 2500 2900 6xl 70 5 14 21 14 20 22 25 12 2640 3080 * yardages given are for long sleeves if working 3/4 length sleeves subtract 40 40 40 50 50 60 80 110 140 140 150 160 180 180 180 180 180 220 220 yards if working short sleeves subtract 50 70 80 90 130 150 200 260 280 290 310 310 340 350 350 350 350 400 400 yards construction this sweater is worked seamlessly in the round from the top down you cast on at the neckline and the yoke is shaped by raglan increases to the underarm sleeve sts are placed on hold on waste yarn the body is completed then sleeves are worked last for help with this project check out our in-depth flax sweater tutorial neckline using smaller needles cast on 68 72 78 84 88 90 96 100 100 104 112 112 112 118 118 124 124 124 128 sts place bor marker and join for working in the round select one of the following two ribbing methods for the neckline ribbing first method the simpler but less structured method is to knit neckline ribbing immediately after casting on work in 1x1 k1 p1 rib for 0 75 0 75 0 75 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 25 1 25 1 25 1 25 1 25 1 25 1 5 1 5 1 5 1 5 switch to larger sleeve sts on hold needles and proceed to neckline increase round ribbing last
